Name: Bar Muscle-up EMOM
Description: Bar Muscle-up EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) 12 is a gymnastics skill workout where athletes perform a set number of bar muscle-ups at the start of each minute for 12 minutes. The focus is on technique, explosiveness, and consistent repetition under moderate fatigue.
Flavor_Text: Bar Muscle-up EMOM – Control the early minutes and let clean movement carry you late.
CoachNotes:
**  
Prioritize form over speed; initiate each rep with a strong kip, keeping the core tight and maintaining hollow-to-arch positions. Cue athletes to drive hips explosively and keep the bar close during the transition. Scale to jumping or banded muscle-ups as needed. Rest remaining time in the minute to maintain quality throughout.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Complete 1-1 Bar Muscle-Ups. If you fail a rep or cannot complete the required reps, switch to 2 Pull-ups for that minute. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Complete 1-3 Bar Muscle-Ups. If you fail a rep or cannot complete the required reps, switch to 5 Pull-ups for that minute. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Complete 1-3 Bar Muscle-Ups. If you fail a rep or cannot complete the required reps, switch to 5 Pull-ups for that minute. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Complete 1-3 Bar Muscle-Ups. If you fail a rep or cannot complete the required reps, switch to 5 Pull-ups for that minute. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: complete 1-3 bar muscle-ups. if you fail a rep or cannot complete the required reps, switch to 5 pull-ups for that minute.
Instructions_Clean: complete 1-3 bar muscle-ups. if you fail a rep or cannot complete the required repetitions, switch to 5 pull-ups for that minute.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Use kip efficiently; consider banded pull-ups to keep turnover high.

Name: The Long Haul
Description: The Long Haul is a grind/endurance workout performed for time. Designed to test sustained effort, it features extended work periods and moderate intensity movements, challenging both your cardiovascular capacity and mental stamina. Consistency and pacing are key as you push through longer sets or distance.
Flavor_Text: The Long Haul – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes:
**  
Begin at a controlled, maintainable pace—avoid going out too fast. Focus on rhythmic breathing and efficient movement patterns. Break large sets into manageable chunks if needed, minimizing rest. Monitor heart rate and stay relaxed through shoulders and grip. Hydrate and keep positive self-talk throughout to stay motivated and finish strong.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions; Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 1 Mile Run, 25 Push Press (22/15 kgs), 1 Mile Run. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 1 Mile Run, 50 Push Press (45/30 kgs), 1 Mile Run. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 1 Mile Run, 50 Push Press (45/30 kgs), 1 Mile Run. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 1 Mile Run, 50 Push Press (45/30 kgs), 1 Mile Run. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 1 mile run, 50 push press (45/30 kgs), 1 mile run.
Instructions_Clean: 1 mile run, 50 push press (45/30 kgs), 1 mile run.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Bear Complex EMOM
Description: The Bear Complex EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) is a high-intensity, full-body barbell workout combining strength and conditioning. Over 15 minutes, athletes perform a sequence of 1 power clean, 1 front squat, 1 push press, 1 back squat, and 1 push press from behind the neck every minute, focusing on fluid movement and technique. Choose a moderate weight to maintain quality and consistency throughout all rounds.
Flavor_Text: Bear Complex EMOM – Interval-style intensity that tests composure under mounting fatigue.
CoachNotes:
**  
Prioritize form over load; start conservatively with weight, especially if new to complex lifts. Efficient barbell cycling and breathing are key—reset your grip and posture between transitions. Aim for consistent pace each minute to avoid early burnout, but ensure every rep is performed with control. Rest the remainder of each minute to prepare for the next.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Complete 1 full "Bear Complex" (Power Clean, Front Squat, Push Press, Back Squat, Push Press) at (30/22 kgs). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Complete 1 full "Bear Complex" (Power Clean, Front Squat, Push Press, Back Squat, Push Press) at (60/45 kgs). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Complete 1 full "Bear Complex" (Power Clean, Front Squat, Push Press, Back Squat, Push Press) at (60/45 kgs). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Complete 1 full "Bear Complex" (Power Clean, Front Squat, Push Press, Back Squat, Push Press) at (60/45 kgs). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: complete 1 full "bear complex" (power clean, front squat, push press, back squat, push press) at (60/45 kgs).
Instructions_Clean: complete 1 full "bear complex" (power clean, front squat, push press, back squat, push press) at (60/45 kgs).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

The Bear Complex EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) is a high-intensity, full-body barbell workout combining strength and conditioning. Over 15 minutes, athletes perform a sequence of 1 power clean, 1 front squat, 1 push press, 1 back squat, and 1 push press from behind the neck every minute, focusing on fluid movement and technique. Choose a moderate weight to maintain quality and consistency throughout all rounds.

**
Description.to: The Bear Complex EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) is a high-intensity, full-body barbell workout combining strength and conditioning. Over 15 minutes, athletes perform a sequence of 1 power clean, 1 front squat, 1 push press, 1 back squat, and 1 push press from behind the neck every minute, focusing on fluid movement and technique. Choose a moderate weight to maintain quality and consistency throughout all rounds.

CoachNotes.from:
**Description:**  
The Bear Complex EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) is a high-intensity, full-body barbell workout combining strength and conditioning. Over 15 minutes, athletes perform a sequence of 1 power clean, 1 front squat, 1 push press, 1 back squat, and 1 push press from behind the neck every minute, focusing on fluid movement and technique. Choose a moderate weight to maintain quality and consistency throughout all rounds.

**CoachNotes:**  
Prioritize form over load; start conservatively with weight, especially if new to complex lifts. Efficient barbell cycling and breathing are key—reset your grip and posture between transitions. Aim for consistent pace each minute to avoid early burnout, but ensure every rep is performed with control. Rest the remainder of each minute to prepare for the next.
CoachNotes.to:
**  
Prioritize form over load; start conservatively with weight, especially if new to complex lifts. Efficient barbell cycling and breathing are key—reset your grip and posture between transitions. Aim for consistent pace each minute to avoid early burnout, but ensure every rep is performed with control. Rest the remainder of each minute to prepare for the next.

Flavor_Text.from: Bear Complex EMOM - Expect sharp efforts and quick transitions; small mistakes add up.
Flavor_Text.to: Bear Complex EMOM – Interval-style intensity that tests composure under mounting fatigue.

Name: Heavy Squats & Cardio
Description: This workout combines heavy barbell squats with intense cardio intervals. Perform sets of weighted squats at high intensity, followed by short bursts of cardio (such as sprints or jump rope), optimizing both strength and cardiovascular endurance in a single session.
Flavor_Text: Heavy Squats & Cardio – Classic for-time intensity: aggressive but controlled from the first rep.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on maintaining proper squat form—chest up, knees tracking over toes, and full depth. Adjust barbell weight to ensure safe, challenging reps. For cardio segments, give maximal effort but prioritize controlled breathing. Rest as needed between rounds to maintain performance quality. Warm up thoroughly and cool down/stretch after the workout.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Back Squats (42/30 kgs), 100m Row. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Back Squats (85/60 kgs), 200m Row. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Back Squats (85/60 kgs), 200m Row. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Back Squats (85/60 kgs), 200m Row. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 back squats (85/60 kgs), 200m row.
Instructions_Clean: 10 back squats (85/60 kgs), 200m row.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Triplet
Description: The Triplet is an 18-minute AMRAP (as many rounds as possible) workout focused on barbell and weightlifting movements. Athletes cycle through three key lifts—commonly power cleans, front squats, and push presses—for a set number of repetitions per round. This high-intensity format promotes strength, muscular endurance, and cardiovascular conditioning, all while reinforcing complex barbell skills.
Flavor_Text: The Triplet – Chip away each round with smooth transitions and smart breaks.
CoachNotes:
**  
Choose a barbell weight that allows you to complete at least the first two rounds unbroken with good form. Prioritize technique under fatigue—maintain a solid core, use efficient breathing, and reset grip as needed. Pace yourself early, aiming for steady, sustainable rounds rather than burning out in the first half. Track your rounds and reps for progress and future scaling.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Power Snatches (22/15 kgs), 7 GHD Sit-ups, 10 Box Jumps (12/10 in). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Power Snatches (45/30 kgs), 15 GHD Sit-ups, 20 Box Jumps (24/20 in). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Power Snatches (45/30 kgs), 15 GHD Sit-ups, 20 Box Jumps (24/20 in). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Power Snatches (45/30 kgs), 15 GHD Sit-ups, 20 Box Jumps (24/20 in). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 power snatches (45/30 kgs), 15 ghd sit-ups, 20 box jumps (24/20 in).
Instructions_Clean: 10 power snatches (45/30 kgs), 15 ghd sit-ups, 20 box jumps (24/20 in).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Death By Clean
Description: "Death By Clean" is an Every Minute On the Minute (EMOM) workout where athletes perform a set number of cleans that increases by one rep each minute. Start with one clean in minute one, two cleans in minute two, and continue adding a rep each minute until failure to complete the required reps within that minute. This workout challenges both muscular endurance and pacing strategy.
Flavor_Text: Death By Clean – Control the early minutes and let clean movement carry you late.
CoachNotes:
**  
- Focus on efficient, consistent form as fatigue builds to reduce injury risk.  
- Use a moderate weight (approx. 60% of 1RM), allowing for multiple reps each minute.  
- Emphasize quick cycle times and intentional rest between reps to manage heart rate.  
- Set up the space for quick barbell access and safe dropping.  
- Cue athletes to break larger sets into manageable chunks as reps increase.  
- Remind athletes to stop if form significantly breaks down.  
- Track the highest successful round for future goal-setting.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Minute 1: 1 Clean (30/22 kgs). Minute 1: 1 Cleans. Minute 1: 1 Cleans... Continue until unable to complete the required reps in the minute. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Minute 1: 1 Clean (60/45 kgs). Minute 2: 2 Cleans. Minute 3: 3 Cleans... Continue until unable to complete the required reps in the minute. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Minute 1: 1 Clean (60/45 kgs). Minute 2: 2 Cleans. Minute 3: 3 Cleans... Continue until unable to complete the required reps in the minute. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Minute 1: 1 Clean (60/45 kgs). Minute 2: 2 Cleans. Minute 3: 3 Cleans... Continue until unable to complete the required reps in the minute. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: minute 1: 1 clean (60/45 kgs). minute 2: 2 cleans. minute 3: 3 cleans... continue until unable to complete the required reps in the minute.
Instructions_Clean: minute 1: 1 clean (60/45 kgs). minute 2: 2 cleans. minute 3: 3 cleans... continue until unable to complete the required repetitions in the minute.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Strict Press Ladder
Description: The Strict Press Ladder is a weightlifting workout where athletes perform increasing repetitions of barbell strict presses at ascending weights, aiming to complete the sequence as quickly as possible ("for time"). The strict press targets shoulder, triceps, and core strength, with each set performed without any leg drive.
Flavor_Text: Strict Press Ladder – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes:
**  
- Emphasize strict form: feet shoulder-width apart, core braced, no knee movement.
- Prioritize proper warm-up, focusing on shoulders and upper back.
- Advise athletes to select weights that allow for unbroken reps with good form.
- Encourage athletes to rest briefly between sets to maintain quality.
- Modify or scale weights as needed for safety and technique.
- Remind athletes to lock out elbows overhead and control the barbell on descent.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Strict Press (17/12 kgs), 10 Toes-to-Bar, 15 Double Unders. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Strict Press (35/25 kgs), 20 Toes-to-Bar, 30 Double Unders. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Strict Press (35/25 kgs), 20 Toes-to-Bar, 30 Double Unders. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Strict Press (35/25 kgs), 20 Toes-to-Bar, 30 Double Unders. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 strict press (35/25 kgs), 20 toes-to-bar, 30 double unders. for time
Instructions_Clean: 10 strict press (35/25 kgs), 20 toes-to-bar, 30 double unders. complete the following for time
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Dumbbell Overhead
Description: The Dumbbell Overhead is a strength and stamina movement where an athlete presses dumbbells or kettlebells overhead from shoulder level until arms are fully extended. This movement targets the shoulders, triceps, upper back, and core stability. It can be performed strictly or with a push press technique. In “For Time” workouts, the goal is to complete the prescribed reps or distance as fast as possible.
Flavor_Text: Dumbbell Overhead – A full-body punch that rewards tidy technique and calm transitions.
CoachNotes:
**  
Maintain a strong, engaged core to avoid overextending the lower back. Keep elbows close to the ears at lockout and fully lock out both arms overhead. Select a weight that allows for unbroken or challenging sets. Prioritize form over speed; unsafe reps are not worth faster time. Scale the load as needed and break reps into manageable sets, especially as fatigue sets in. Breath control is key: exhale during the press, inhale as you lower the weights.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 25 ft Dual Dumbbell Overhead Lunge (12/7 kgs), 7 Burpees over Dumbbells, 5 Strict Pull-ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 50 ft Dual Dumbbell Overhead Lunge (25/15 kgs), 15 Burpees over Dumbbells, 10 Strict Pull-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 50 ft Dual Dumbbell Overhead Lunge (25/15 kgs), 15 Burpees over Dumbbells, 10 Strict Pull-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 50 ft Dual Dumbbell Overhead Lunge (25/15 kgs), 15 Burpees over Dumbbells, 10 Strict Pull-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 50 ft dual dumbbell overhead lunge (25/15 kgs), 15 burpees over dumbbells, 10 strict pull-ups.
Instructions_Clean: 50 ft dual dumbbell overhead lunge (25/15 kgs), 15 burpees over dumbbells, 10 strict pull-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Heavy Deadlift Chipper
Description: The Heavy Deadlift Chipper is a high-intensity, barbell-based workout designed to test maximal strength, muscular endurance, and mental grit. Athletes complete a set amount of heavy deadlift reps, often broken into decreasing rep schemes (e.g., 21-15-9), aiming to finish all prescribed work as fast as possible. This "for time" chipper format means each rep must be completed before moving to the next, demanding efficient movement and pacing.
Flavor_Text: Heavy Deadlift Chipper – A straightforward suffer-fest; clean mechanics matter more than hero splits.
CoachNotes:
**  
Prioritize perfect deadlift form—keep your back flat, engage your lats, and drive through your heels. Choose a heavy load that is challenging but allows for crisp reps without significant form breakdown. Break reps into manageable sets with short, planned rests to avoid burnout. Focus on bracing your core before every pull and control the descent to protect your back. Breathe steadily and keep transitions tight to maximize efficiency and minimize wasted time. Always scale weight based on individual capacity to maintain technique and safety.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Deadlifts (72/50 kgs), Ring Muscle-Ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Deadlifts (145/100 kgs), Ring Muscle-Ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Deadlifts (145/100 kgs), Ring Muscle-Ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Deadlifts (145/100 kgs), Ring Muscle-Ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: deadlifts (145/100 kgs), ring muscle-ups. for time
Instructions_Clean: deadlifts (145/100 kgs), ring muscle-ups. complete the following for time
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Maintain neutral spine; use mixed grip for heavy sets if needed.

Name: Wall Ball & Carry EMOM
Description: Wall Ball & Carry EMOM: Every minute on the minute for 21 minutes, alternate between sets of wall balls (full-depth squat to throw with medicine ball at a wall target) and carry drills (farmer’s carry or other loaded carries). Rotate movements per minute as prescribed, focusing on consistent pacing.
Flavor_Text: Wall Ball & Carry EMOM – Control the early minutes and let clean movement carry you late.
CoachNotes:
**  
Pick a wall ball weight that allows unbroken sets with good form. Carries: Keep chest tall, core braced, and walk with controlled steps. Prioritize quality movement over speed—maintain steady breathing, and avoid rushing transitions. Pacing is key: challenge your capacity but prevent burnout before the last round.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Minute 1: 10 Wall Balls (5/2 kgs). Minute 1: 50 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (15/12 kgs), right arm). Minute 1: 50 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (15/12 kgs), left arm). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Minute 1: 20 Wall Balls (10/5 kgs). Minute 2: 100 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (30/25 kgs), right arm). Minute 3: 100 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (30/25 kgs), left arm). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Minute 1: 20 Wall Balls (10/5 kgs). Minute 2: 100 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (30/25 kgs), right arm). Minute 3: 100 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (30/25 kgs), left arm). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Minute 1: 20 Wall Balls (10/5 kgs). Minute 2: 100 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (30/25 kgs), right arm). Minute 3: 100 ft Single Arm Farmer's Carry (30/25 kgs), left arm). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: minute 1: 20 wall balls (10/5 kgs). minute 2: 100 ft single arm farmer's carry (30/25 kgs), right arm). minute 3: 100 ft single arm farmer's carry (30/25 kgs), left arm). for time
Instructions_Clean: minute 1: 20 wall balls (10/5 kgs). minute 2: 100 ft single arm farmer's carry (30/25 kgs), right arm). minute 3: 100 ft single arm farmer's carry (30/25 kgs), left arm). complete the following for time
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Set a rhythm and target the top of the wall mark consistently.

Description.from:
**  
Wall Ball & Carry EMOM: Every minute on the minute for 21 minutes, alternate between sets of wall balls (full-depth squat to throw with medicine ball at a wall target) and carry drills (farmer’s carry or other loaded carries). Rotate movements per minute as prescribed, focusing on consistent pacing.

**
Description.to: Wall Ball & Carry EMOM: Every minute on the minute for 21 minutes, alternate between sets of wall balls (full-depth squat to throw with medicine ball at a wall target) and carry drills (farmer’s carry or other loaded carries). CoachNotes.from:
**Description:**  
Wall Ball & Carry EMOM: Every minute on the minute for 21 minutes, alternate between sets of wall balls (full-depth squat to throw with medicine ball at a wall target) and carry drills (farmer’s carry or other loaded carries). Rotate movements per minute as prescribed, focusing on consistent pacing.

**CoachNotes:**  
Pick a wall ball weight that allows unbroken sets with good form. Carries: Keep chest tall, core braced, and walk with controlled steps. Prioritize quality movement over speed—maintain steady breathing, and avoid rushing transitions. Pacing is key: challenge your capacity but prevent burnout before the last round.

Flavor_Text.to: Wall Ball & Carry EMOM – Control the early minutes and let clean movement carry you late.

Name: The Olympic Complex
Description: The Olympic Complex is a high-intensity, barbell-focused workout performed for time. Athletes cycle through a series of Olympic weightlifting movements—including the clean, jerk, and snatch—executing a predetermined number of repetitions of each in sequence without dropping the bar. This demanding workout tests strength, power, technique, and stamina, aiming to complete all repetitions as quickly as possible with proper form.
Flavor_Text: The Olympic Complex – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes:
**  
- Prioritize technique over speed, especially as fatigue sets in.  
- Choose a weight that allows for unbroken sets, but still challenges your capacity.  
- Warm up thoroughly, focusing on mobility and movement patterns for each Olympic lift.  
- Breathing and bracing are key—reset between movements if needed.  
- Scale load or reps for athletes still mastering Olympic lifts, and substitute with power variations if mobility is restricted.  
- Monitor form closely to minimize risk of injury, and enforce full range of motion on every rep.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Overhead Squats (25/17 kgs), 7 Calorie Bike, 10 Ring Dips. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Overhead Squats (50/35 kgs), 15 Calorie Bike, 20 Ring Dips. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Overhead Squats (50/35 kgs), 15 Calorie Bike, 20 Ring Dips. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Overhead Squats (50/35 kgs), 15 Calorie Bike, 20 Ring Dips. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 overhead squats (50/35 kgs), 15 calorie bike, 20 ring dips.
Instructions_Clean: 10 overhead squats (50/35 kgs), 15 calorie bike, 20 ring dips.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Barbell & Run AMRAP
Description: Barbell & Run AMRAP (AMRAP 16) is a 16-minute circuit alternating between barbell lifts and running. Move through as many rounds as possible, performing a set number of barbell reps—such as deadlifts, cleans, or thrusters—followed immediately by a set running distance (e.g., 200m/400m). Repeat this sequence, tracking rounds and reps completed within the time cap.
Flavor_Text: Barbell & Run AMRAP – Pure mixed-modal engine work; consistency across rounds is the real score.
CoachNotes:
**  
Prioritize controlled technique on barbell lifts; choose a weight you can maintain for strong, consistent sets. Pace the run—start steady, but keep transitions quick. Prepare to push through fatigue in later rounds. Focus on efficient breathing and movement quality throughout. Record your total rounds and partial reps for progress tracking.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 200m Run, 7 Power Cleans (25/17 kgs). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 400m Run, 15 Power Cleans (50/35 kgs). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 400m Run, 15 Power Cleans (50/35 kgs). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 400m Run, 15 Power Cleans (50/35 kgs). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 400m run, 15 power cleans (50/35 kgs).
Instructions_Clean: 400m run, 15 power cleans (50/35 kgs).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Interval Builder
Description: This workout features 6 rounds of high-intensity intervals. Each round includes 2 minutes of maximum effort work (as many reps or cycles as possible—AMRAP), followed by 1 minute of rest. The focus is on intensity, pushing yourself during the work period, and recovering fully during rest to maintain performance across all rounds.
Flavor_Text: Interval Builder – A skill-forward piece; keep mechanics clean and ego low.
CoachNotes:
**  
Aim to maintain a consistent pace in each work interval. Track your reps to ensure you’re staying close to your target each round. Use the rest period for controlled breathing and active recovery—stand tall, shake out your limbs, and prepare mentally for the next interval. Quality of movement comes before speed; prioritize good form to maximize results and reduce injury risk.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions; Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Max reps of: 2 Pull-ups, 5 Push-ups, 7 Air Squats. Score is total reps accumulated. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Max reps of: 5 Pull-ups, 10 Push-ups, 15 Air Squats. Score is total reps accumulated. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Max reps of: 5 Pull-ups, 10 Push-ups, 15 Air Squats. Score is total reps accumulated. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Max reps of: 5 Pull-ups, 10 Push-ups, 15 Air Squats. Score is total reps accumulated. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: max reps of: 5 pull-ups, 10 push-ups, 15 air squats. score is total reps accumulated.
Instructions_Clean: max repetitions of: 5 pull-ups, 10 push-ups, 15 air squats. score is total repetitions accumulated.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Use kip efficiently; consider banded pull-ups to keep turnover high.

Name: Heavy Thruster 10
Description: Perform 10 heavy thrusters (barbell or dumbbells) every minute on the minute (EMOM) for 10 minutes. Focus on full-depth squats and strong overhead lockouts. Pace yourself to complete the reps each minute, aiming for consistent form and speed.
Flavor_Text: Heavy Thruster 10 – Stay sharp each round; smooth reps and quick resets beat hero bursts.
CoachNotes:
**  
Choose a weight you can maintain for all rounds without failure. Keep core engaged and drive powerfully through your hips. Breathe rhythmically—inhale down, exhale up. If you can't finish within the minute, reduce load or reps. Prioritize quality over speed as fatigue sets in.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Complete 2 Thrusters (25/17 kgs). Scale weight down if you fail to complete 2 reps unbroken for the minute. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Complete 5 Thrusters (50/35 kgs). Scale weight down if you fail to complete 5 reps unbroken for the minute. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Complete 5 Thrusters (50/35 kgs). Scale weight down if you fail to complete 5 reps unbroken for the minute. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Complete 5 Thrusters (50/35 kgs). Scale weight down if you fail to complete 5 reps unbroken for the minute. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: complete 5 thrusters (50/35 kgs). scale weight down if you fail to complete 5 reps unbroken for the minute.
Instructions_Clean: complete 5 thrusters (50/35 kgs). scale weight down if you fail to complete 5 repetitions unbroken for the minute.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Break thrusters into manageable sets; keep front rack tight.

Name: Kettlebell Swing & Burpee
Description: This workout alternates explosive kettlebell swings with full-body burpees, utilizing either a kettlebell or dumbbell. Perform the movements for time, aiming to complete all prescribed reps as quickly as possible while maintaining proper form and intensity.
Flavor_Text: Kettlebell Swing & Burpee – Big sets, big fatigue; smart breaking keeps you moving when it hurts.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on hinging at the hips and engaging your core during kettlebell swings to protect your lower back. Keep your chest up and drive with your glutes. For burpees, maintain a strong plank position during the push-up and use your hips to explode upwards. Pace yourself—smooth, consistent reps outperform early burnout. Choose a weight that allows unbroken swings with good technique.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: American Kettlebell Swings (12/8 kg), Burpee Pull-ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: American Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg), Burpee Pull-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: American Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg), Burpee Pull-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: American Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg), Burpee Pull-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: american kettlebell swings (24/16 kg), burpee pull-ups.
Instructions_Clean: american kettlebell swings (24/16 kg), burpee pull-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Aim for unbroken swings if possible; hinge from the hips. Use kip efficiently; consider banded pull-ups to keep turnover high.

Name: The Benchmark D
Description: The Benchmark D is a grind-style, endurance workout performed for time. It challenges your stamina and pacing across multiple movements with a focus on sustained effort. The workout typically includes several rounds of matched-rep bodyweight and cardio movements, demanding both muscular and aerobic endurance.
Flavor_Text: The Benchmark D – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes:
**  
Pace yourself early and aim for consistent, manageable sets. Breathe steadily and focus on efficient movement to conserve energy. Break reps before fatigue sets in to avoid long rest periods. Keep transitions quick and maintain good form. Track your time to gauge progress on future attempts.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 25 Box Jumps (12/10 in), 25 Push Presses (17/12 kgs), 25 Knees-to-Elbows, 25 Hip Extensions. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 50 Box Jumps (24/20 in), 50 Push Presses (35/25 kgs), 50 Knees-to-Elbows, 50 Hip Extensions. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 50 Box Jumps (24/20 in), 50 Push Presses (35/25 kgs), 50 Knees-to-Elbows, 50 Hip Extensions. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 50 Box Jumps (24/20 in), 50 Push Presses (35/25 kgs), 50 Knees-to-Elbows, 50 Hip Extensions. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 50 box jumps (24/20 in), 50 push presses (35/25 kgs), 50 knees-to-elbows, 50 hip extensions.
Instructions_Clean: 50 box jumps (24/20 in), 50 push presses (35/25 kgs), 50 knees-to-elbows, 50 hip extensions.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Strict Pull EMOM
Description: Strict Pull EMOM is a pacing workout performed Every Minute on the Minute (EMOM) for 14 minutes. At the start of each minute, complete a set number of strict pull-ups, then rest for the remainder of the minute. Focus on controlled, full-range movements with no kipping or swinging.
Flavor_Text: Strict Pull EMOM – Interval-style intensity that tests composure under mounting fatigue.
CoachNotes:
**  
Choose a pull-up rep count that allows for consistent technique across all rounds—quality over quantity. Scale by reducing reps or using assistance bands if needed. Engage your scapulae, keep core tight, and maintain a steady rhythm. Aim to finish each set within 30–40 seconds to allow for adequate rest between rounds. Monitor grip fatigue and adjust pace if form starts to break down.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Odd Minutes: 2 Strict Toes-to-Bar. Even Minutes: 2 Strict Pull-ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Odd Minutes: 5 Strict Toes-to-Bar. Even Minutes: 5 Strict Pull-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Odd Minutes: 5 Strict Toes-to-Bar. Even Minutes: 5 Strict Pull-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Odd Minutes: 5 Strict Toes-to-Bar. Even Minutes: 5 Strict Pull-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: odd minutes: 5 strict toes-to-bar. even minutes: 5 strict pull-ups.
Instructions_Clean: odd minutes: 5 strict toes-to-bar. even minutes: 5 strict pull-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Use kip efficiently; consider banded pull-ups to keep turnover high.

Name: Heavy Clean & Jerk
Description: The Heavy Clean & Jerk is an advanced weightlifting movement performed with a barbell. The exercise consists of two sequential actions: first, explosively lifting the barbell from the floor to the shoulders (clean), then driving it overhead to full extension (jerk). Performed for time, this workout demands maximum power, strength, and speed, targeting the entire body with emphasis on legs, core, shoulders, and back.
Flavor_Text: Heavy Clean & Jerk – Classic for-time intensity: aggressive but controlled from the first rep.
CoachNotes: Focus on a powerful hip extension during the clean and maintain a neutral spine. Use your legs aggressively when standing up and dip efficiently for the jerk. Prioritize quality technique throughout to ensure safety, especially under heavy load. Rest strategically between reps if needed, and use a hook grip for better bar control. Warm up thoroughly, mobilize wrists and hips, and scale appropriately if your form starts to break down.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Clean & Jerk (35/25 kgs), 100m Run. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Clean & Jerk (70/50 kgs), 200m Run. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Clean & Jerk (70/50 kgs), 200m Run. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Clean & Jerk (70/50 kgs), 200m Run. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: clean & jerk (70/50 kgs), 200m run.
Instructions_Clean: clean & jerk (70/50 kgs), 200m run.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Description.from:
Description:  
The Heavy Clean & Jerk is an advanced weightlifting movement performed with a barbell. The exercise consists of two sequential actions: first, explosively lifting the barbell from the floor to the shoulders (clean), then driving it overhead to full extension (jerk). Performed for time, this workout demands maximum power, strength, and speed, targeting the entire body with emphasis on legs, core, shoulders, and back.

CoachNotes:  
Focus on a powerful hip extension during the clean and maintain a neutral spine. Use your legs aggressively when standing up and dip efficiently for the jerk. Prioritize quality technique throughout to ensure safety, especially under heavy load. Rest strategically between reps if needed, and use a hook grip for better bar control. Warm up thoroughly, mobilize wrists and hips, and scale appropriately if your form starts to break down.

Flavor_Text.to: Heavy Clean & Jerk – Classic for-time intensity: aggressive but controlled from the first rep.

Name: Bodyweight Hero
Description: Bodyweight Hero is a high-intensity, travel-friendly workout designed for speed and endurance, requiring no equipment. Perform a series of classic bodyweight movements—such as push-ups, squats, lunges, and burpees—with the goal to complete all prescribed reps as fast as possible ("For Time"). This workout targets full-body strength, cardio capacity, and muscular endurance, making it ideal for any fitness level and perfect for home, hotel, or outdoor training.
Flavor_Text: Bodyweight Hero – Big sets, big fatigue; smart breaking keeps you moving when it hurts.
CoachNotes: Move continuously; avoid red-lining; break push-ups early.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 12 Hand Release Push-ups, 25 Walking Lunges, 50 Double Unders. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 25 Hand Release Push-ups, 50 Walking Lunges, 100 Double Unders. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 25 Hand Release Push-ups, 50 Walking Lunges, 100 Double Unders. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 25 Hand Release Push-ups, 50 Walking Lunges, 100 Double Unders. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 25 hand release push-ups, 50 walking lunges, 100 double unders.
Instructions_Clean: 25 hand release push-ups, 50 walking lunges, 100 double unders.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Rope Climb & Row
Description: Rope Climb & Row is a 13-minute AMRAP (As Many Rounds As Possible) workout combining gymnastics skill and cardiovascular endurance. Athletes complete a set number of rope climbs followed by a rowing distance in each round, aiming to perform as many full rounds as possible within the time cap.
Flavor_Text: Rope Climb & Row – Volume adds up fast, so break early and stay moving.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on efficient rope climb technique (legs, locks, and controlled descents) to conserve grip and energy. Pace your rowing to avoid burnout; maintain steady but sustainable splits. Prioritize safety on the rope, especially under fatigue. Scale rope climbs as needed (e.g., partial climbs or foot-assisted) to maintain consistent movement throughout the AMRAP.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 1 Legless Rope Climb (or 1 standard), 7/6 Calorie Row, 5 Handstand Push-ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 1 Legless Rope Climb (or 2 standard), 15/12 Calorie Row, 10 Handstand Push-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 1 Legless Rope Climb (or 2 standard), 15/12 Calorie Row, 10 Handstand Push-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 1 Legless Rope Climb (or 2 standard), 15/12 Calorie Row, 10 Handstand Push-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 1 legless rope climb (or 2 standard), 15/12 calorie row, 10 handstand push-ups.
Instructions_Clean: 1 legless rope climb (or 2 standard), 15/12 calorie row, 10 handstand push-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Barbell Conditioning
Description: Barbell Conditioning (AMRAP/Interval, AMRAP 15) is a high-intensity strength and endurance workout. Using a barbell, you’ll perform a sequence of lifts (such as deadlifts, hang cleans, and shoulder-to-overheads) as many rounds as possible (AMRAP) in a 15-minute period. This workout challenges both your muscular endurance and cardiovascular capacity, aiming to build strength while improving conditioning and calorie burn.
Flavor_Text: Barbell Conditioning – Pure mixed-modal engine work; consistency across rounds is the real score.
CoachNotes:
**  
Choose a barbell weight that allows you to maintain proper form and continuous movement. Pace yourself early—don’t go out too fast. Focus on smooth, efficient transitions between movements and minimize rest. Maintain a tight core throughout all lifts and prioritize quality reps over speed as fatigue sets in. Record the total completed rounds and additional reps for progress tracking. Warm up thoroughly and cool down after.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 2 Front Squats (30/22 kgs), 5 Bar Facing Burpees, 7 Wall Balls (5/2 kgs). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 5 Front Squats (60/45 kgs), 10 Bar Facing Burpees, 15 Wall Balls (10/5 kgs). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 5 Front Squats (60/45 kgs), 10 Bar Facing Burpees, 15 Wall Balls (10/5 kgs). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 5 Front Squats (60/45 kgs), 10 Bar Facing Burpees, 15 Wall Balls (10/5 kgs). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 5 front squats (60/45 kgs), 10 bar facing burpees, 15 wall balls (10/5 kgs).
Instructions_Clean: 5 front squats (60/45 kgs), 10 bar facing burpees, 15 wall balls (10/5 kgs).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Long Steady Distance
Description: Long Steady Distance (LSD) is an endurance-focused workout where you perform a single cardiovascular exercise—such as running, cycling, or rowing—at a consistent, sustainable pace over an extended period or distance, aiming to finish "for time." The goal is to build aerobic capacity, muscular stamina, and mental resilience.
Flavor_Text: Long Steady Distance – An engine test; settle into a pace you can actually hold.
CoachNotes:
**  
Keep a steady pace at 60–75% of your maximum effort to avoid early fatigue. Stay relaxed and focus on controlled breathing. Prioritize proper form throughout the workout to prevent overuse injuries. This session is about consistency and endurance, not speed—finishing strong is the key. Hydrate before and after, and don’t skip your cooldown.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 500m Row, 25 Air Squats, 12 Strict Press (17/12 kgs). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 1000m Row, 50 Air Squats, 25 Strict Press (35/25 kgs). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 1000m Row, 50 Air Squats, 25 Strict Press (35/25 kgs). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 1000m Row, 50 Air Squats, 25 Strict Press (35/25 kgs). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 1000m row, 50 air squats, 25 strict press (35/25 kgs).
Instructions_Clean: 1000m row, 50 air squats, 25 strict press (35/25 kgs).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Bike & Burpee Ladder
Description: The Bike & Burpee Ladder is a high-intensity cardio workout completed for time. Start with a set number of calories on the bike and a small number of burpees. In each round, increase the calories and burpees in a ladder format. Continue ascending until the final round is finished as quickly as possible.
Flavor_Text: Bike & Burpee Ladder – Simple on paper, brutal if you disrespect the distance.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on maintaining a steady bike pace and smooth transitions between movements. Pace burpees efficiently, using controlled movement to avoid burnout. Breathe deeply and modulate intensity for consistent performance throughout. Scale reps or calories as needed to match fitness level. Aim for quick, quality reps under fatigue.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Calorie Bike, 5 Burpees; 10 Calorie Bike, 10 Burpees; 15 Calorie Bike, 15 Burpees; 20 Calorie Bike, 20 Burpees. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Calorie Bike, 10 Burpees; 20 Calorie Bike, 20 Burpees; 30 Calorie Bike, 30 Burpees; 40 Calorie Bike, 40 Burpees. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Calorie Bike, 10 Burpees; 20 Calorie Bike, 20 Burpees; 30 Calorie Bike, 30 Burpees; 40 Calorie Bike, 40 Burpees. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Calorie Bike, 10 Burpees; 20 Calorie Bike, 20 Burpees; 30 Calorie Bike, 30 Burpees; 40 Calorie Bike, 40 Burpees. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 calorie bike, 10 burpees; 20 calorie bike, 20 burpees; 30 calorie bike, 30 burpees; 40 calorie bike, 40 burpees.
Instructions_Clean: 10 calorie bike, 10 burpees; 20 calorie bike, 20 burpees; 30 calorie bike, 30 burpees; 40 calorie bike, 40 burpees.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Odd Object Carry EMOM
Description: Odd Object Carry EMOM: Every minute on the minute for 20 minutes, carry a challenging dumbbell or kettlebell for a set distance or duration. Alternate the carry style each minute—such as suitcase, farmer's, or overhead carry—to train grip strength, core stability, and unilateral control.
Flavor_Text: Odd Object Carry EMOM – Control the early minutes and let clean movement carry you late.
CoachNotes:
**  
Select an object heavy enough to be challenging but safe for unbroken carries. Focus on upright posture, shoulders back, and tight core throughout. Switch hands or carry styles each minute for balanced development. Prioritize control over speed to reduce risk of injury; quality reps over quantity.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Odd Minutes: 50 ft Sandbag/Atlas Stone Carry (Heavy). Even Minutes: 7 Kettlebell Swings (12/8 kg). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Odd Minutes: 100 ft Sandbag/Atlas Stone Carry (Heavy). Even Minutes: 15 Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Odd Minutes: 100 ft Sandbag/Atlas Stone Carry (Heavy). Even Minutes: 15 Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Odd Minutes: 100 ft Sandbag/Atlas Stone Carry (Heavy). Even Minutes: 15 Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: odd minutes: 100 ft sandbag/atlas stone carry (heavy). even minutes: 15 kettlebell swings (24/16 kg).
Instructions_Clean: odd minutes: 100 ft sandbag/atlas stone carry (heavy). even minutes: 15 kettlebell swings (24/16 kg).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Aim for unbroken swings if possible; hinge from the hips.

Name: Ski-erg Intervals
Description: Ski-erg Intervals involve alternating periods of high-intensity effort and rest using the ski-erg machine. Each round consists of 1 minute of powerful skiing, followed by 1 minute of complete rest. This cardio-focused workout builds aerobic capacity, upper body endurance, and overall conditioning.
Flavor_Text: Ski-erg Intervals – Clean movement and sensible pacing will carry you further than heroics.
CoachNotes: Maintain consistent pacing throughout all intervals—aim for similar distances each round. Focus on explosive hip extension and crisp pole pulls. Recover fully during rest periods to preserve intensity. Monitor your stroke rate and keep technique efficient, driving from your core and legs rather than relying only on your arms.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Max Calorie Ski. Score is total calories accumulated over 5 working minutes. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Max Calorie Ski. Score is total calories accumulated over 10 working minutes. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Max Calorie Ski. Score is total calories accumulated over 10 working minutes. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Max Calorie Ski. Score is total calories accumulated over 10 working minutes. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: max calorie ski. score is total calories accumulated over 10 working minutes. for time
Instructions_Clean: max calorie ski. score is total calories accumulated over 10 working minutes. complete the following for time
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: High-volume Wall Balls
Description: A high-volume Wall Ball workout challenges your endurance and mental grit. Athletes repeatedly throw a medicine ball to a target at a prescribed height, performing a full squat each rep. This grind-style workout is typically performed “for time,” requiring you to complete a set number of reps (e.g., 100–150) as fast as possible. Pace and strategy are key for success.
Flavor_Text: High-volume Wall Balls – A full-body punch that rewards tidy technique and calm transitions.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on hitting proper depth in every squat and consistent target height each rep. Breathe rhythmically and avoid burning out early—break reps into manageable sets to minimize rest. Keep the chest tall, catch the ball with soft hands, and drive through the heels. If technique breaks down or fatigue sets in, shorten sets but limit rest to maintain intensity.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility; Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions; Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Wall Balls (5/2 kgs) in the first round. Every round, perform 5 Pull-ups and 5 Push-ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Wall Balls (10/5 kgs) in the first round. Every round, perform 10 Pull-ups and 10 Push-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Wall Balls (10/5 kgs) in the first round. Every round, perform 10 Pull-ups and 10 Push-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Wall Balls (10/5 kgs) in the first round. Every round, perform 10 Pull-ups and 10 Push-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: wall balls (10/5 kgs) in the first round. every round, perform 10 pull-ups and 10 push-ups.
Instructions_Clean: wall balls (10/5 kgs) in the first round. every round, perform 10 pull-ups and 10 push-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Set a rhythm and target the top of the wall mark consistently. Use kip efficiently; consider banded pull-ups to keep turnover high.

Name: Heavy Double Dumbbell
Description: The Heavy Double Dumbbell workout is a high-intensity, for-time challenge using two dumbbells or kettlebells. Athletes perform a prescribed sequence of movements—such as double dumbbell cleans, front squats, or shoulder-to-overhead—moving quickly while maintaining proper form. The focus is on pushing heavy weight while completing the required reps as fast as possible.
Flavor_Text: Heavy Double Dumbbell – Classic for-time intensity: aggressive but controlled from the first rep.
CoachNotes:
**  
Prioritize safety and mechanics over speed, especially with heavy loads. Maintain a neutral spine and solid core engagement throughout. Scale weights as needed to ensure all reps are performed with good technique. Breathe consistently, pace yourself, and use controlled movements to avoid burnout early in the workout. Rest as needed, but keep breaks brief for an optimal finish time.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Dual Dumbbell Snatches (12/7 kgs), 7 Alternating V-ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Dual Dumbbell Snatches (25/15 kgs), 15 Alternating V-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Dual Dumbbell Snatches (25/15 kgs), 15 Alternating V-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Dual Dumbbell Snatches (25/15 kgs), 15 Alternating V-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 dual dumbbell snatches (25/15 kgs), 15 alternating v-ups.
Instructions_Clean: 10 dual dumbbell snatches (25/15 kgs), 15 alternating v-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Grip Destroyer AMRAP
Description: Grip Destroyer AMRAP is a 15-minute "as many rounds as possible" workout focused on challenging your grip strength through gymnastics and skill-based movements. You’ll rotate through exercises such as pull-ups, toes-to-bar, hang holds, and farmer carries, testing your endurance and grip under fatigue.
Flavor_Text: Grip Destroyer AMRAP – Chip away each round with smooth transitions and smart breaks.
CoachNotes:
**  
Prioritize quality form over speed—especially as grip fatigue sets in. Break reps early to avoid failure, and maintain active shoulders during hanging movements for safety. Breathe steadily during carries, and shake out hands between rounds as needed. Adjust movements as needed (e.g., use banded pull-ups or lighter weights) to maintain consistency throughout the AMRAP.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Kettlebell Cleans (12/8 kg, 2 per arm), 5 Toes-to-Bar, 50 ft Handstand Walk (or 2 Wall Walks). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Kettlebell Cleans (24/16 kg, 5 per arm), 10 Toes-to-Bar, 100 ft Handstand Walk (or 5 Wall Walks). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Kettlebell Cleans (24/16 kg, 5 per arm), 10 Toes-to-Bar, 100 ft Handstand Walk (or 5 Wall Walks). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Kettlebell Cleans (24/16 kg, 5 per arm), 10 Toes-to-Bar, 100 ft Handstand Walk (or 5 Wall Walks). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 kettlebell cleans (24/16 kg, 5 per arm), 10 toes-to-bar, 100 ft handstand walk (or 5 wall walks).
Instructions_Clean: 10 kettlebell cleans (24/16 kg, 5 per arm), 10 toes-to-bar, 100 ft handstand walk (or 5 wall walks).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Barbell And Rope
Description: This workout is a 16-minute EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) alternating between two movements: barbell lifts (such as deadlifts, cleans, or front squats) and rope exercises (double-unders, single-unders, or battle ropes). Odd minutes: perform a set number of barbell reps. Even minutes: complete a set number of rope reps. Maintain form and controlled pacing throughout.
Flavor_Text: Barbell And Rope – Manageable work, small windows; don’t waste time between stations.
CoachNotes:
**  
Choose barbell weight and rope rep scheme allowing consistent completion within 40 seconds each minute. Focus on proper technique for both movements; avoid rushing through reps. Use remaining time each minute to rest and recover. Scale load or reps to ensure sustainability for the full 16 minutes. Track rounds and quality over total volume.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Odd Minutes: 6 Deadlifts (35/25 kgs). Even Minutes: 25 Double-Unders. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Odd Minutes: 12 Deadlifts (70/50 kgs). Even Minutes: 50 Double-Unders. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Odd Minutes: 12 Deadlifts (70/50 kgs). Even Minutes: 50 Double-Unders. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Odd Minutes: 12 Deadlifts (70/50 kgs). Even Minutes: 50 Double-Unders. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: odd minutes: 12 deadlifts (70/50 kgs). even minutes: 50 double-unders. for time
Instructions_Clean: odd minutes: 12 deadlifts (70/50 kgs). even minutes: 50 double-unders. complete the following for time
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Maintain neutral spine; use mixed grip for heavy sets if needed.

Name: The Long Cardio Chipper
Description: The Long Cardio Chipper is an endurance-focused workout designed to test your stamina and mental toughness. You'll work through a sequential list of high-rep cardio movements, completing all reps of one exercise before moving to the next. The goal is to finish the entire sequence as quickly as possible.
Flavor_Text: The Long Cardio Chipper – A full-body punch that rewards tidy technique and calm transitions.
CoachNotes: Pace yourself early and find a sustainable rhythm. Focus on consistent movement, smart pacing, and strategic breaking of reps if needed. Maintain good form under fatigue and use efficient transitions between movements. Hydrate adequately and mentally prepare for a grind—this is about steady effort, not sprint speed.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Box Jumps, Calorie Row (10-8-6-4-2 Cal), Kettlebell Swings (12/8 kg). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Box Jumps, Calorie Row (20-16-12-8-4 Cal), Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Box Jumps, Calorie Row (20-16-12-8-4 Cal), Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Box Jumps, Calorie Row (20-16-12-8-4 Cal), Kettlebell Swings (24/16 kg). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: box jumps, calorie row (20-16-12-8-4 cal), kettlebell swings (24/16 kg).
Instructions_Clean: box jumps, calorie row (20-16-12-8-4 cal), kettlebell swings (24/16 kg).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Aim for unbroken swings if possible; hinge from the hips.

Name: Overhead Stamina
Description: Overhead Stamina is a 12-minute AMRAP (As Many Rounds As Possible) barbell workout designed to build overhead strength and muscular endurance. Athletes perform repeated rounds of overhead lifting—most commonly using movements like push press, strict press, or overhead squats—aiming for maximum rounds or reps within the time cap.
Flavor_Text: Overhead Stamina – A grinder; steady round times beat one big opening sprint.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on maintaining proper overhead positioning: lock out elbows, keep core tight, and avoid overextending through the lower back. Choose a challenging but manageable weight to sustain movement for the full 12 minutes. Prioritize quality reps and smooth transitions between sets; break early if necessary to avoid form breakdown. Breathe steadily, brace before each lift, and emphasize shoulder stability throughout.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 4 Overhead Squats (22/15 kgs), 4 Bar Facing Burpees. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 8 Overhead Squats (45/30 kgs), 8 Bar Facing Burpees. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 8 Overhead Squats (45/30 kgs), 8 Bar Facing Burpees. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 8 Overhead Squats (45/30 kgs), 8 Bar Facing Burpees. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 8 overhead squats (45/30 kgs), 8 bar facing burpees.
Instructions_Clean: 8 overhead squats (45/30 kgs), 8 bar facing burpees.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Interval Mix
Description: Interval Mix (EMOM/Pacing, EMOM 27) is a structured endurance and strength session, performed “Every Minute on the Minute” for 27 minutes. Athletes complete specific movements or reps each minute, then use the remaining time to rest. This pacing workout balances intensity and recovery, optimizing work capacity and technique under fatigue.
Flavor_Text: Interval Mix – Stay sharp each round; smooth reps and quick resets beat hero bursts.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on consistent movement quality throughout each round. Scale reps or load to ensure you can complete each interval within 45 seconds, reserving time to recover for the next minute. Maintain steady breathing and monitor your pace to prevent burnout. Use this session to dial in efficiency and mental resilience.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Minute 1: 7/6 Calorie Bike. Minute 1: 5 Clean & Jerks (22/15 kgs). Minute 1: 5 Strict Push-ups. (Repeat 4 times) - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Minute 1: 15/12 Calorie Bike. Minute 2: 10 Clean & Jerks (45/30 kgs). Minute 3: 10 Strict Push-ups. (Repeat 9 times) - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Minute 1: 15/12 Calorie Bike. Minute 2: 10 Clean & Jerks (45/30 kgs). Minute 3: 10 Strict Push-ups. (Repeat 9 times) - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Minute 1: 15/12 Calorie Bike. Minute 2: 10 Clean & Jerks (45/30 kgs). Minute 3: 10 Strict Push-ups. (Repeat 9 times) - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: minute 1: 15/12 calorie bike. minute 2: 10 clean & jerks (45/30 kgs). minute 3: 10 strict push-ups. (repeat 9 times)
Instructions_Clean: minute 1: 15/12 calorie bike. minute 2: 10 clean & jerks (45/30 kgs). minute 3: 10 strict push-ups. (repeat 9 times)
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Running & Air Squat
Description: This workout alternates between running (a monostructural/cardio movement) and air squats (a functional, lower-body bodyweight exercise) performed as fast as possible ("for time"). The goal is to complete the given distances and repetitions quickly while maintaining proper form.
Flavor_Text: Running & Air Squat – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.
CoachNotes:
**  
Focus on efficient running mechanics and consistent pacing—avoid starting out too fast. During air squats, prioritize depth (hips below parallel), a neutral spine, and full hip extension at the top. Monitor breathing to aid transition between movements. Scale distances or reps as needed to finish within 12–20 minutes for most athletes.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 400m Run, 25 Air Squats. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 800m Run, 50 Air Squats. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 800m Run, 50 Air Squats. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 800m Run, 50 Air Squats. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 800m run, 50 air squats.
Instructions_Clean: 800m run, 50 air squats.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Description.from:
**  
This workout alternates between running (a monostructural/cardio movement) and air squats (a functional, lower-body bodyweight exercise) performed as fast as possible ("for time"). The goal is to complete the given distances and repetitions quickly while maintaining proper form.

**
Description.to: This workout alternates between running (a monostructural/cardio movement) and air squats (a functional, lower-body bodyweight exercise) performed as fast as possible ("for time"). The goal is to complete the given distances and repetitions quickly while maintaining proper form.

CoachNotes.from:
**Description:**  
This workout alternates between running (a monostructural/cardio movement) and air squats (a functional, lower-body bodyweight exercise) performed as fast as possible ("for time"). The goal is to complete the given distances and repetitions quickly while maintaining proper form.

**CoachNotes:**  
Focus on efficient running mechanics and consistent pacing—avoid starting out too fast. During air squats, prioritize depth (hips below parallel), a neutral spine, and full hip extension at the top. Monitor breathing to aid transition between movements. Scale distances or reps as needed to finish within 12–20 minutes for most athletes.
CoachNotes.to:
**  
Focus on efficient running mechanics and consistent pacing—avoid starting out too fast. During air squats, prioritize depth (hips below parallel), a neutral spine, and full hip extension at the top. Monitor breathing to aid transition between movements. Scale distances or reps as needed to finish within 12–20 minutes for most athletes.

Flavor_Text.from: Running & Air Squat - Expect sharp efforts and quick transitions; small mistakes add up.
Flavor_Text.to: Running & Air Squat – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.

Name: Gymnastic Skill AMRAP
Description: Perform as many rounds and reps as possible (AMRAP) in 14 minutes, focusing on gymnastics movements and skills. The intent is to challenge body control, coordination, and stamina while practicing foundational or advanced gymnastics exercises such as pull-ups, handstand holds, push-ups, or toes-to-bar.
Flavor_Text: Gymnastic Skill AMRAP – Volume adds up fast, so break early and stay moving.
CoachNotes:
**  
Prioritize form over speed to maximize skill development and reduce injury risk. Scale movements as needed to maintain technique throughout the AMRAP. Warm up thoroughly, focus on full range of motion, and pace yourself early—14 minutes is a sustained effort. Track reps and rounds for progress measurement.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 1 Ring Muscle-Ups, 3 Squat Snatches (22/15 kgs), 4 Chest-to-Bar Pull-ups. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 3 Ring Muscle-Ups, 6 Squat Snatches (45/30 kgs), 9 Chest-to-Bar Pull-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 3 Ring Muscle-Ups, 6 Squat Snatches (45/30 kgs), 9 Chest-to-Bar Pull-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 3 Ring Muscle-Ups, 6 Squat Snatches (45/30 kgs), 9 Chest-to-Bar Pull-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 3 ring muscle-ups, 6 squat snatches (45/30 kgs), 9 chest-to-bar pull-ups.
Instructions_Clean: 3 ring muscle-ups, 6 squat snatches (45/30 kgs), 9 chest-to-bar pull-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Assault Bike EMOM
Description: Assault Bike EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) for 15 minutes focuses on consistent pacing and intensity. Each minute, aim to complete a targeted calorie or distance goal on the bike, followed by rest for the remainder of the minute. Repeat this cycle for 15 rounds.
Flavor_Text: Assault Bike EMOM – Interval-style intensity that tests composure under mounting fatigue.
CoachNotes:
**  
Maintain steady effort—avoid sprinting early to prevent burnout. Adjust calories or distance goal to match ability while ensuring each interval can be sustained. Focus on powerful, controlled pedal strokes, strong posture, and breathing. Track output each round to monitor pacing.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Complete 7/6 Calorie Bike. If the task is completed early, rest for the remainder of the minute. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Complete 15/12 Calorie Bike. If the task is completed early, rest for the remainder of the minute. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Complete 15/12 Calorie Bike. If the task is completed early, rest for the remainder of the minute. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Complete 15/12 Calorie Bike. If the task is completed early, rest for the remainder of the minute. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: complete 15/12 calorie bike. if the task is completed early, rest for the remainder of the minute.
Instructions_Clean: complete 15/12 calorie bike. if the task is completed early, rest for the remainder of the minute.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.
