Name: Farmer's Run
Description:
**Farmer's Run (Grind/Endurance, For Time) - Description:**

The Farmer’s Run is an endurance workout focused on grip strength, core stability, and cardiovascular conditioning. Athletes carry heavy weights (such as dumbbells or kettlebells) in both hands while running or walking a set distance as fast as possible. This "for time" challenge pushes mental toughness, tests overall body endurance, and improves functional strength, simulating real-life loaded carries. Proper posture and steady pacing are key to maintaining form and completing the effort efficiently.
Flavor_Text: Farmer's Run – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes: For Farmer's Run: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8; Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 100m Run, 50m Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 10 Burpees. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 200m Run, 100m Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 20 Burpees. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 200m Run, 100m Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 20 Burpees. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 200m Run, 100m Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 20 Burpees. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 200m run, 100m dual kettlebell farmer's carry (heavy), 20 burpees.
Instructions_Clean: 200m run, 100m dual kettlebell farmer's carry (heavy), 20 burpees.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Aim for unbroken swings if possible; hinge from the hips.

Name: Hyrox Sprint EMOM
Description: The Hyrox Sprint EMOM is a high-intensity 16-minute “Every Minute On the Minute” (EMOM) workout that blends running efforts with functional strength training. Athletes complete a set task at the start of each minute, alternating between sprints and prescribed bodyweight or equipment-based exercises, maintaining consistent pacing and minimal rest. This format promotes cardiovascular fitness, muscular endurance, and race-day readiness, mimicking the fast-paced transitions and work-rest ratios seen in Hyrox events. Ideal for improving speed, power, and efficiency under fatigue.
Flavor_Text: Hyrox Sprint EMOM – Short, punchy intervals that reward tight pacing and crisp transitions.
CoachNotes: For Hyrox Sprint EMOM: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Min 1: 250m Row (Fast Pace). Min 1: 7 Burpees. Min 1: 200m Run (Fast Pace). Min 2: 7 Wall Balls. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Min 1: 500m Row (Fast Pace). Min 2: 15 Burpees. Min 3: 400m Run (Fast Pace). Min 4: 15 Wall Balls. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Min 1: 500m Row (Fast Pace). Min 2: 15 Burpees. Min 3: 400m Run (Fast Pace). Min 4: 15 Wall Balls. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Min 1: 500m Row (Fast Pace). Min 2: 15 Burpees. Min 3: 400m Run (Fast Pace). Min 4: 15 Wall Balls. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: min 1: 500m row (fast pace). min 2: 15 burpees. min 3: 400m run (fast pace). min 4: 15 wall balls.
Instructions_Clean: min 1: 500m row (fast pace). min 2: 15 burpees. min 3: 400m run (fast pace). min 4: 15 wall balls.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Set a rhythm and target the top of the wall mark consistently.

Name: The Cardio Mix
Description: The Cardio Mix is a high-intensity, monostructural workout focused on cardiovascular endurance. This "For Time" workout challenges you to complete a set sequence of cardio movements—like running, rowing, cycling, or jump rope—as quickly as possible. It develops aerobic capacity, stamina, and mental toughness. Suitable for all fitness levels, the Cardio Mix delivers a full-body calorie burn and boosts overall conditioning.
Flavor_Text: The Cardio Mix – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.
CoachNotes: For The Cardio Mix: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 500m Bike, 250m Row, 100m Run. Rest 45 seconds between rounds. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 1000m Bike, 500m Row, 200m Run. Rest 90 seconds between rounds. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 1000m Bike, 500m Row, 200m Run. Rest 90 seconds between rounds. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 1000m Bike, 500m Row, 200m Run. Rest 90 seconds between rounds. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 1000m bike, 500m row, 200m run. rest 90 seconds between rounds.
Instructions_Clean: 1000m bike, 500m row, 200m run. rest 90 seconds between rounds.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Ultimate Grind
Description: The Ultimate Grind is a challenging endurance workout focused on pushing your physical and mental limits. This "for time" routine combines high-repetition movements and sustained cardiovascular effort designed to build grit, muscular stamina, and aerobic capacity. Expect a demanding sequence meant to test your persistence, requiring consistent pacing and efficient technique throughout. Ideal for athletes seeking to enhance work capacity, fortitude, and overall conditioning. Suitable for advanced fitness levels.
Flavor_Text: The Ultimate Grind – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes: For The Ultimate Grind: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 500m Ski, 40 Burpee Broad Jumps, 100m Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 50 Wall Balls. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 1000m Ski, 80 Burpee Broad Jumps, 200m Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 100 Wall Balls. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 1000m Ski, 80 Burpee Broad Jumps, 200m Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 100 Wall Balls. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 1000m Ski, 80 Burpee Broad Jumps, 200m Farmer's Carry (Heavy), 100 Wall Balls. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 1000m ski, 80 burpee broad jumps, 200m farmer's carry (heavy), 100 wall balls.
Instructions_Clean: 1000m ski, 80 burpee broad jumps, 200m farmer's carry (heavy), 100 wall balls.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Sprint 500/500
Description: The Sprint 500/500 is a high-intensity, monostructural cardio workout performed for time. Complete a 500-meter row followed immediately by a 500-meter run, pushing for maximum speed and effort. This workout targets aerobic capacity, power output, and overall cardiovascular endurance, making it ideal for athletes seeking to improve conditioning with a minimal, measurable format. Rest as needed post-effort and record your total completion time.
Flavor_Text: Sprint 500/500 – Long, steady output; aim for a rhythm you could explain, not survive.
CoachNotes: For Sprint 500/500: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 250m Ski (Max Effort), 250m Row (Max Effort). Rest 1m 0s between rounds. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 500m Ski (Max Effort), 500m Row (Max Effort). Rest 2m 0s between rounds. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 500m Ski (Max Effort), 500m Row (Max Effort). Rest 2m 0s between rounds. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 500m Ski (Max Effort), 500m Row (Max Effort). Rest 2m 0s between rounds. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 500m ski (max effort), 500m row (max effort). rest 2m 0s between rounds.
Instructions_Clean: 500m ski (max effort), 500m row (max effort). rest 2m 0s between rounds.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Short Rest
Description: "The Short Rest" is a high-intensity, cardiovascular workout designed to challenge your aerobic capacity and endurance. This for-time workout features monostructural movements—such as running, rowing, cycling, or jumping rope—performed at maximal effort with brief, controlled rest intervals. The primary goal is to complete the prescribed distance or repetitions in the shortest time possible, pushing your heart rate while maintaining efficient movement. This WOD is scalable for any fitness level, making it ideal for both beginners and advanced athletes seeking to improve stamina and recovery speed.
Flavor_Text: The Short Rest – An engine test; settle into a pace you can actually hold.
CoachNotes: For The Short Rest: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 125m Row, 125m Ski. Rest 15 seconds after each 250m set. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 250m Row, 250m Ski. Rest 30 seconds after each 500m set. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 250m Row, 250m Ski. Rest 30 seconds after each 500m set. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 250m Row, 250m Ski. Rest 30 seconds after each 500m set. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 250m row, 250m ski. rest 30 seconds after each 500m set.
Instructions_Clean: 250m row, 250m ski. rest 30 seconds after each 500m set.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Max Calorie 60s

Name: The Power 300

Description.from:
**Description:**  
The Power 300 is a high-intensity cardio workout designed to rapidly improve endurance, stamina, and cardiovascular health. Completing a total of 300 repetitions of monostructural movements (such as running, rowing, biking, or jump rope) as fast as possible, this "For Time" challenge pushes athletes to maintain speed while managing fatigue. Ideal for all fitness levels seeking a demanding yet straightforward conditioning session that builds grit and mental toughness.
Description.to: The Power 300 is a high-intensity cardio workout designed to rapidly improve endurance, stamina, and cardiovascular health. Completing a total of 300 repetitions of monostructural movements (such as running, rowing, biking, or jump rope) as fast as possible, this "For Time" challenge pushes athletes to maintain speed while managing fatigue. Ideal for all fitness levels seeking a demanding yet straightforward conditioning session that builds grit and mental toughness.

Flavor_Text.from: The Power 300 - Expect sharp efforts and quick transitions; small mistakes add up.
Flavor_Text.to: The Power 300 – Let patience do the work; speed only matters once you’re halfway in.

Name: Ski Sprint Complex
Description: The Ski Sprint Complex is a high-intensity interval workout designed to boost cardiovascular endurance and power. Performed on a ski ergometer, this EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) session lasts for 10 rounds. At the start of each minute, complete a prescribed, challenging ski sprint effort, then use any remaining time for recovery. This format maximizes calorie burn, improves aerobic capacity, and develops explosive upper and lower body strength. Suitable for all fitness levels with scalable intensity.
Flavor_Text: Ski Sprint Complex – Interval-style intensity that tests composure under mounting fatigue.
CoachNotes: For Ski Sprint Complex: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 100m Ski. Rest the remainder of the minute. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 200m Ski. Rest the remainder of the minute. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 200m Ski. Rest the remainder of the minute. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 200m Ski. Rest the remainder of the minute. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 200m ski. rest the remainder of the minute. for time
Instructions_Clean: 200m ski. rest the remainder of the minute. complete the following for time
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Rowing Ladder Up
Description: The Rowing Ladder Up workout is a monostructural, cardio-focused session performed for time on the rowing machine. Starting with a lower distance, each round increases the rowing distance—typically in set increments—challenging both aerobic capacity and mental endurance. The goal is to complete each interval as quickly as possible while progressing "up the ladder" of increasing distances, maintaining consistent pacing and proper rowing technique throughout. This workout effectively builds cardiovascular fitness and muscular stamina.
Flavor_Text: Rowing Ladder Up – Simple on paper, brutal if you disrespect the distance.
CoachNotes: For Rowing Ladder Up: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 50m Row, 100m Row, 150m Row, 200m Row, 250m Row. Rest 22 seconds between distances. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 100m Row, 200m Row, 300m Row, 400m Row, 500m Row. Rest 45 seconds between distances. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 100m Row, 200m Row, 300m Row, 400m Row, 500m Row. Rest 45 seconds between distances. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 100m Row, 200m Row, 300m Row, 400m Row, 500m Row. Rest 45 seconds between distances. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 100m row, 200m row, 300m row, 400m row, 500m row. rest 45 seconds between distances.
Instructions_Clean: 100m row, 200m row, 300m row, 400m row, 500m row. rest 45 seconds between distances.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Double 400
Description: The Double 400 is a high-intensity cardio workout focused on building speed, endurance, and metabolic conditioning. Athletes complete two 400-meter runs as quickly as possible, separated by a brief rest or set transition. This sprint-style effort is designed to challenge cardiovascular capacity, burn calories, and improve overall running performance. Suitable for all levels, it can be performed on a track, treadmill, or any marked, safe running space.
Flavor_Text: The Double 400 – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.
CoachNotes: For The Double 400: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 200m Ski, 5 Push-ups. Rest 45 seconds. 200m Row, 5 Air Squats. Rest 45 seconds. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 400m Ski, 10 Push-ups. Rest 90 seconds. 400m Row, 10 Air Squats. Rest 90 seconds. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 400m Ski, 10 Push-ups. Rest 90 seconds. 400m Row, 10 Air Squats. Rest 90 seconds. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 400m Ski, 10 Push-ups. Rest 90 seconds. 400m Row, 10 Air Squats. Rest 90 seconds. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 400m ski, 10 push-ups. rest 90 seconds. 400m row, 10 air squats. rest 90 seconds.
Instructions_Clean: 400m ski, 10 push-ups. rest 90 seconds. 400m row, 10 air squats. rest 90 seconds.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Calorie Burn 4x
Description: Calorie Burn 4x is a high-intensity monostructural cardio workout focused on maximizing calorie expenditure in the shortest time possible. Featuring repeated bursts of effort on a single cardio machine—such as the rower, assault bike, or treadmill—you’ll complete four fast-paced rounds “for time.” Push hard each round, aiming for consistent pacing and maximum output. This format efficiently boosts cardiovascular endurance, metabolism, and overall conditioning.
Flavor_Text: Calorie Burn 4x – Let patience do the work; speed only matters once you’re halfway in.
CoachNotes: For Calorie Burn 4x: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 2 sets of 7/6 Calorie Ski. Rest 15 seconds. 2 sets of 7/6 Calorie Row. Rest 15 seconds. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 4 sets of 15/12 Calorie Ski. Rest 30 seconds. 4 sets of 15/12 Calorie Row. Rest 30 seconds. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 4 sets of 15/12 Calorie Ski. Rest 30 seconds. 4 sets of 15/12 Calorie Row. Rest 30 seconds. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 4 sets of 15/12 Calorie Ski. Rest 30 seconds. 4 sets of 15/12 Calorie Row. Rest 30 seconds. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 4 sets of 15/12 calorie ski. rest 30 seconds. 4 sets of 15/12 calorie row. rest 30 seconds.
Instructions_Clean: 4 sets of 15/12 calorie ski. rest 30 seconds. 4 sets of 15/12 calorie row. rest 30 seconds.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The 200/20
Description: The 200/20 workout is a high-intensity, cardio-focused challenge performed “For Time.” Athletes complete 200 meters of a monostructural cardio movement (such as running, rowing, biking, or skiing) followed by 20 reps of a bodyweight movement (e.g., air squats, push-ups, or sit-ups). This sequence is repeated for a set number of rounds, aiming to finish as quickly as possible. The emphasis is on combining steady-paced cardio with functional bodyweight exercises to boost endurance, speed, and overall conditioning.
Flavor_Text: The 200/20 – Long, steady output; aim for a rhythm you could explain, not survive.
CoachNotes: For The 200/20: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 100m Row, 10 Air Squats. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 200m Row, 20 Air Squats. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 200m Row, 20 Air Squats. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 200m Row, 20 Air Squats. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 200m row, 20 air squats.
Instructions_Clean: 200m row, 20 air squats.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: 4K Row Challenge
Description: The 4K Row Challenge is a cardio-focused, monostructural workout where you row 4,000 meters as fast as possible. This workout tests endurance, pacing strategy, and overall cardiovascular fitness. Aim to maintain a consistent stroke rate and strong technique throughout the distance. Your goal is to complete the row in the shortest time possible, tracking your split times to help improve future performance.
Flavor_Text: 4K Row Challenge – Simple on paper, brutal if you disrespect the distance.
CoachNotes: For 4K Row Challenge: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 2000m Row. Every 500m, perform 1m 0s Plank Hold. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 4000m Row. Every 1000m, perform 1m 0s Plank Hold. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 4000m Row. Every 1000m, perform 1m 0s Plank Hold. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 4000m Row. Every 1000m, perform 1m 0s Plank Hold. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 4000m row. every 1000m, perform 1m 0s plank hold.
Instructions_Clean: 4000m row. every 1000m, perform 1m 0s plank hold.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Mixed 6K
Description: The Mixed 6K workout is a monostructural/cardio challenge focused on completing a total distance of 6,000 meters using one or a combination of cardio machines such as the rower, assault bike, treadmill, or ski erg. This for-time workout emphasizes sustained effort, pacing strategy, and cardiovascular endurance. Aim to finish the distance as quickly as possible while maintaining consistent intensity and form throughout.
Flavor_Text: Mixed 6K – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.
CoachNotes: For Mixed 6K: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 1500m Ski Erg, 1500m Row. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 3000m Ski Erg, 3000m Row. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 3000m Ski Erg, 3000m Row. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 3000m Ski Erg, 3000m Row. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 3000m ski erg, 3000m row.
Instructions_Clean: 3000m ski erg, 3000m row.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Long EMOM Row
Description: A Long EMOM Row (Every Minute On the Minute, 20 minutes) focuses on sustained pacing and aerobic capacity. Each minute, row a designated number of calories or meters, then rest for the remainder of the minute. Adjust pace to maintain consistency throughout, with effort targeted at 65–75% of max intensity. This workout builds endurance, reinforces rowing technique, and encourages mental discipline. Ideal for all fitness levels—modify targets as needed.
Flavor_Text: Long EMOM Row – Manageable work, small windows; don’t waste time between stations.
CoachNotes: For Long EMOM Row: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 125m Row. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 250m Row. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 250m Row. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 250m Row. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 250m row.
Instructions_Clean: 250m row.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

The goal is to maintain a consistent, challenging pace throughout the duration. This session develops cardiovascular endurance, stamina, and mental fortitude while allowing you to track improvements over time.
Flavor_Text: The 15m 0s Pace – Versatile enough for many levels, tough enough to stay interesting.

Name: Calorie Marathon
Description: Calorie Marathon is a monostructural cardio workout done "For Time," where athletes aim to burn a prescribed number of calories as quickly as possible using equipment like a rower, assault bike, ski erg, or treadmill. The focus is on sustained, high-output effort, pacing strategy, and cardiovascular endurance. This workout challenges both mental toughness and aerobic capacity, making it suitable for all fitness levels with scalable calorie targets.
Flavor_Text: Calorie Marathon – An engine test; settle into a pace you can actually hold.
CoachNotes: For Calorie Marathon: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 50/37 Calorie Ski, 50/37 Calorie Row. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 100/75 Calorie Ski, 100/75 Calorie Row. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 100/75 Calorie Ski, 100/75 Calorie Row. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 100/75 Calorie Ski, 100/75 Calorie Row. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions_Clean: 100/75 calorie ski, 100/75 calorie row.
TrainingGoals: High Volume Calorie Burn, Mental Grit
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Ski-row 100/50
Description: The Ski-row 100/50 is a high-intensity, monostructural cardio workout performed for time. It involves completing 100 calories (men) or 50 calories (women) on a ski erg as quickly as possible. This workout primarily targets the upper body, core, and cardiovascular system, offering a full-body conditioning challenge that tests endurance, power, and pacing strategy. Proper technique and consistent effort are key to achieving the best time.
Flavor_Text: The Ski-row 100/50 – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.
CoachNotes: For The Ski-row 100/50: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Description.from:
**Description:**  
The Ski-row 100/50 is a high-intensity, monostructural cardio workout performed for time. It involves completing 100 calories (men) or 50 calories (women) on a ski erg as quickly as possible. This workout primarily targets the upper body, core, and cardiovascular system, offering a full-body conditioning challenge that tests endurance, power, and pacing strategy. Proper technique and consistent effort are key to achieving the best time.
Description.to: The Ski-row 100/50 is a high-intensity, monostructural cardio workout performed for time. It involves completing 100 calories (men) or 50 calories (women) on a ski erg as quickly as possible. This workout primarily targets the upper body, core, and cardiovascular system, offering a full-body conditioning challenge that tests endurance, power, and pacing strategy. Proper technique and consistent effort are key to achieving the best time.

Flavor_Text.from: The Ski-Row 100/50 - Brutal but fair; pace wisely and prioritize technique.
Flavor_Text.to: The Ski-row 100/50 – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.

Name: Steady State 45
Description: Steady State 45 is a monostructural cardio workout, performed for distance over 45 minutes at a consistent, moderate intensity. The goal is to maintain a steady pace, maximizing aerobic endurance and building cardiovascular efficiency without redlining. Ideal activities include running, cycling, rowing, or swimming—choose one modality and focus on smooth, controlled effort throughout the session.
Flavor_Text: Steady State 45 – Clean movement and sensible pacing will carry you further than heroics.
CoachNotes: For Steady State 45: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Name: Alternating Cals
Description: This EMOM (Every Minute on the Minute) workout spans 14 minutes. You will alternate calories each minute, performing a set number of calories on a cardio machine (such as a rower, bike, or ski erg). Start strong in the first minute, then use the second minute for active recovery at a moderate pace, continuing to alternate intensity every subsequent minute. This format builds both aerobic capacity and recovery speed, encouraging athletes to maintain consistent effort and efficient pacing throughout the session.
Flavor_Text: Alternating Cals – Interval-style intensity that tests composure under mounting fatigue.
CoachNotes: For Alternating Cals: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Odd: 15/12 Calorie Ski. Even: 15/12 Calorie Row. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Burpee Buffer
Description: The Burpee Buffer is an 18-minute EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) workout that emphasizes both pacing and intensity. At the start of each minute, perform a set number of burpees, then use any time left in the minute to rest before the next round begins. The challenge lies in maintaining consistent effort and movement quality throughout all 18 rounds, building cardiovascular endurance, explosive strength, and mental stamina. Use a rep scheme that is challenging but sustainable, aiming to finish each set with at least 10-20 seconds of rest.
Flavor_Text: The Burpee Buffer – Short, punchy intervals that reward tight pacing and crisp transitions.
CoachNotes: For The Burpee Buffer: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Min 1: 15 Burpees. Min 2: 200m Row. Min 3: 200m Ski. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Name: Ski-row AMRAP 10
Description: The Ski-row AMRAP 10 is a high-intensity, monostructural cardio workout where you alternate between the ski erg and rowing machine for maximum combined meters in 10 minutes. Work at a challenging, steady pace, switching between modalities as needed. Focus on smooth, powerful strokes and efficient transitions to sustain effort and maximize distance covered in the AMRAP. Perfect for building endurance, improving aerobic capacity, and testing mental toughness.
Flavor_Text: Ski-row AMRAP 10 – Simple on paper, brutal if you disrespect the distance.
CoachNotes: For Ski-row AMRAP 10: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Name: High Rep Push-up
Description: A high-rep push-up EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) workout challenges your muscular endurance and pacing skills. For EMOM 16, perform a set number of push-ups at the start of every minute for 16 minutes. After completing your reps, rest for the remainder of the minute before starting again. This approach trains consistent work capacity, improves upper body endurance, and builds mental toughness while emphasizing proper push-up form and controlled breathing. Adjust rep count to match your fitness level.
Flavor_Text: High Rep Push-up – Control the early minutes and let clean movement carry you late.
CoachNotes: For High Rep Push-up: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Name: 20/20 Pacing
Description: 20/20 Pacing is a cardiovascular endurance workout performed as an AMRAP (As Many Rounds As Possible) in 20 minutes, focusing on consistent pacing and sustained intensity. This session uses monostructural movements—such as rowing, running, cycling, or jumping rope—to build aerobic capacity. Aim to maintain steady effort, recording rounds or calories completed, and focus on controlled breathing and efficient movement technique throughout the session. This workout is ideal for improving cardiovascular health, stamina, and recovery capacity.
Flavor_Text: 20/20 Pacing – Let patience do the work; speed only matters once you’re halfway in.
CoachNotes: For 20/20 Pacing: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.

Name: Calorie Sprint EMOM
Description: Calorie Sprint EMOM is a high-intensity interval workout structured as "Every Minute On the Minute" (EMOM) for 12 minutes. At the start of each minute, sprint to burn a set number of calories on cardio equipment (such as a rower, bike, or ski erg). Use the remainder of the minute to recover before the next sprint. This workout targets cardiovascular endurance, explosiveness, and calorie burn while building pacing discipline and work capacity.
Flavor_Text: Calorie Sprint EMOM – Interval-style intensity that tests composure under mounting fatigue.
CoachNotes: For Calorie Sprint EMOM: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.

Name: The Gymnastic Tax
Description:
**Workout:** The Gymnastic Tax (EMOM 15)

**Description:**  
This is a 15-minute EMOM (Every Minute On the Minute) workout focused on building gymnastic skill stamina and pacing. Each minute, perform a set number of challenging gymnastic movements—such as pull-ups, toes-to-bar, push-ups, or handstand holds—followed by rest for the remainder of the minute. The aim is to maintain consistent form, technique, and rep count each round, refining movement efficiency under fatigue. Adjust movement progressions to your skill level. Perfect for developing upper body muscular endurance and aerobic capacity.
Flavor_Text: The Gymnastic Tax – Short, punchy intervals that reward tight pacing and crisp transitions.
CoachNotes: For The Gymnastic Tax: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.

Name: Long Interval AMRAP
Description: Long Interval AMRAP is a high-intensity cardiovascular workout performed for 30 minutes. AMRAP stands for "As Many Rounds As Possible." In this monostructural cardio session, you’ll cycle through a set of endurance-based movements such as running, rowing, or cycling, aiming to complete as many rounds as possible within the time limit. This format maximizes aerobic capacity, builds mental grit, and enhances stamina. Track your completed rounds for personal progress and motivation.
Flavor_Text: Long Interval AMRAP – Simple on paper, brutal if you disrespect the distance.
CoachNotes: For Long Interval AMRAP: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Name: Row/air Squat EMOM
Description:
**Workout Name:** Row/Air Squat EMOM  
**Type:** EMOM (Every Minute on the Minute)  
**Duration:** 15 minutes  
**Structure:** Alternate between rowing and air squats every minute.

**Description:**  
This 15-minute EMOM alternates between two movements for a full-body conditioning workout. At the start of each minute, perform a set distance on the rower (e.g., 150 meters) or a set number of air squats (e.g., 15-20 reps), switching exercises every minute. Rest for the remainder of the minute after completing the task. This pacing approach develops cardiovascular endurance, leg strength, and stamina while encouraging consistent effort and proper form across all rounds.  

**Goals:**  
- Improve aerobic capacity  
- Build muscular endurance in the legs  
- Enhance pacing and recovery skills  

**Equipment Needed:** Rower, timer (or clock)  

**Modifications:**  
- Adjust row distance or squat reps for your fitness level  
- Substitute bodyweight reverse lunges if needed
Flavor_Text: Row/air Squat EMOM – Manageable work, small windows; don’t waste time between stations.
CoachNotes: For Row/air Squat EMOM: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

This 15-minute EMOM alternates between two movements for a full-body conditioning workout. At the start of each minute, perform a set distance on the rower (e.g., 150 meters) or a set number of air squats (e.g., 15-20 reps), switching exercises every minute. Rest for the remainder of the minute after completing the task. This pacing approach develops cardiovascular endurance, leg strength, and stamina while encouraging consistent effort and proper form across all rounds.  

**Goals:**  
- Improve aerobic capacity  
- Build muscular endurance in the legs  
- Enhance pacing and recovery skills  

**Equipment Needed:** Rower, timer (or clock)  

**Modifications:**  
- Adjust row distance or squat reps for your fitness level  
- Substitute bodyweight reverse lunges if needed

Flavor_Text.from: Row/Air Squat EMOM - Expect sharp efforts and quick transitions; small mistakes add up.
Flavor_Text.to: Row/air Squat EMOM – Manageable work, small windows; don’t waste time between stations.

Name: Ski/double Under AMRAP
Description: This 15-minute AMRAP (As Many Rounds As Possible) workout combines ski erg intervals and double unders to challenge both cardiovascular endurance and coordination. Athletes will continuously rotate between short bursts on the ski erg and sets of double unders, aiming to complete as many rounds as possible within the time limit. This format encourages sustained effort, efficient pacing, and skill refinement under fatigue, making it an effective full-body conditioning session.
Flavor_Text: Ski/double Under AMRAP – Pure mixed-modal engine work; consistency across rounds is the real score.
CoachNotes: For Ski/double Under AMRAP: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 75 Double Unders, 5/3 Calorie Ski. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 150 Double Unders, 10/7 Calorie Ski. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 150 Double Unders, 10/7 Calorie Ski. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 150 Double Unders, 10/7 Calorie Ski. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 150 double unders, 10/7 calorie ski. for time
Instructions_Clean: 150 double unders, 10/7 calorie ski. complete the following for time
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Triple Threat Cardio
Description: Triple Threat Cardio is a high-intensity, monostructural workout designed to elevate your heart rate and build cardiovascular endurance. For time, you'll perform three distinct cardio modalities back-to-back, pushing your aerobic capacity as you race against the clock. This efficient, challenging format boosts calorie burn, improves stamina, and keeps training varied and engaging.
Flavor_Text: Triple Threat Cardio – An engine test; settle into a pace you can actually hold.
CoachNotes: For Triple Threat Cardio: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 500m Row, 500m Ski, 15/12 Calorie Bike. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 500m row, 500m ski, 15/12 calorie bike.
Instructions_Clean: 500m row, 500m ski, 15/12 calorie bike.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Row/ski/thruster
Description: This workout combines rowing, ski erg, and thrusters in a continuous, high-intensity endurance grind. The goal is to complete all assigned reps and distances as quickly as possible. Each movement targets different muscle groups while keeping the heart rate elevated, promoting cardiovascular endurance, muscular stamina, and total-body conditioning. Suitable for athletes seeking a challenging, full-body effort to test pacing, grit, and consistency. Finish "For Time" to measure work capacity and improvement over repeated sessions.
Flavor_Text: Row/ski/thruster – A straightforward suffer-fest; clean mechanics matter more than hero splits.
CoachNotes: For Row/ski/thruster: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 250m Row, 10 Thrusters (37/12.4 kgs), 250m Ski. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 500m Row, 20 Thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 500m Ski. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 500m Row, 20 Thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 500m Ski. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 500m Row, 20 Thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 500m Ski. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 500m row, 20 thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 500m ski.
Instructions_Clean: 500m row, 20 thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 500m ski.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Break thrusters into manageable sets; keep front rack tight.

Name: The Wall Ball Hybrid
Description:
**The Wall Ball Hybrid (Grind/Endurance, For Time)**  
This high-intensity endurance workout blends wall balls with complementary movements for a challenging total-body grind. Designed for time, it tests muscular stamina, cardiovascular endurance, and mental grit. Athletes alternate wall balls—squatting and throwing a medicine ball to a target—with exercises such as burpees, box jumps, or running. The goal: finish all prescribed reps as quickly as possible, maintaining consistent effort and proper form throughout. Expect full-body engagement, elevated heart rate, and improved conditioning.
Flavor_Text: The Wall Ball Hybrid – Big sets, big fatigue; smart breaking keeps you moving when it hurts.
CoachNotes: For The Wall Ball Hybrid: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 25 Wall Balls (20/6.4 kgs), 250m Row, 25 AbMat Sit-ups. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 25 Wall Balls (20/6.4 kgs), 250m Row, 25 AbMat Sit-ups. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 25 Wall Balls (20/6.4 kgs), 250m Row, 25 AbMat Sit-ups. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 25 wall balls (20/6.4 kgs), 250m row, 25 abmat sit-ups.
Instructions_Clean: 25 wall balls (20/6.4 kgs), 250m row, 25 abmat sit-ups.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Set a rhythm and target the top of the wall mark consistently.

Name: The Heavy Row
Description: The Heavy Row (Grind/Endurance, For Time) is a high-intensity rowing workout designed to improve strength and cardiovascular endurance. Athletes use a rowing machine with increased resistance or added weight, aiming to complete a set distance or calories as quickly as possible. This workout emphasizes consistent effort, muscular endurance, and mental toughness, challenging both the upper and lower body in a full-body, time-focused grind. Proper rowing technique and pacing are key to maximize efficiency and results.
Flavor_Text: The Heavy Row – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes: For The Heavy Row: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5 Deadlifts (112/35.1 kgs), 250m Row, 5 Box Jumps. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10 Deadlifts (225/70.3 kgs), 500m Row, 10 Box Jumps. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10 Deadlifts (225/70.3 kgs), 500m Row, 10 Box Jumps. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10 Deadlifts (225/70.3 kgs), 500m Row, 10 Box Jumps. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10 deadlifts (225/70.3 kgs), 500m row, 10 box jumps.
Instructions_Clean: 10 deadlifts (225/70.3 kgs), 500m row, 10 box jumps.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Maintain neutral spine; use mixed grip for heavy sets if needed.

Name: Bike/ski/burpee
Description: Bike/ski/burpee is a high-intensity, monostructural cardio workout performed for time. Athletes complete a sequence of calories on the bike or ski erg followed by burpees, aiming to finish as quickly as possible. This workout boosts cardiovascular endurance, calorie burn, and overall conditioning. Suitable for all fitness levels, it can be scaled by adjusting reps, calories, or pace.
Flavor_Text: Bike/ski/burpee – Long, steady output; aim for a rhythm you could explain, not survive.
CoachNotes: For Bike/ski/burpee: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Name: Running Ski Repeater
Description: The Running Ski Repeater is a monostructural, cardio-focused workout performed for time. It combines intervals of treadmill or outdoor running with ski ergometer sprints in a repetitive sequence. This workout challenges cardiovascular endurance, leg drive, and overall aerobic capacity. Aim to maintain consistent pace and smooth transitions between running and ski efforts to optimize performance. Adjust intensity based on fitness level, and ensure proper warm-up and cool-down.
Flavor_Text: Running Ski Repeater – An engine test; settle into a pace you can actually hold.
CoachNotes: For Running Ski Repeater: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 800m Run, 500m Ski. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions_Clean: 800m run, 500m ski.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Single Arm Tax
Description: The Single Arm Tax is a grind/endurance workout performed for time. This workout challenges unilateral strength, muscular endurance, and cardiovascular stamina by alternating high-repetition, single-arm movements. Focus on maintaining strict form, controlling each rep, and minimizing rest to test both your strength and conditioning. This workout is ideal for building grip strength, core stability, and resilience under fatigue.
Flavor_Text: The Single Arm Tax – A straightforward suffer-fest; clean mechanics matter more than hero splits.
CoachNotes: For The Single Arm Tax: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Name: Row/squat Clean
Description: This workout challenges both cardiovascular endurance and full-body strength by combining intense rowing intervals with squat cleans. Athletes alternate between sustained efforts on the rower and powerful squat clean repetitions, pushing metabolic conditioning and functional movement capacity. The grind/endurance focus encourages steady pacing and resilience, testing overall stamina as participants aim to complete the required rounds or repetitions as fast as possible. Ideal for developing aerobic capacity, explosive hip drive, and total-body coordination under fatigue.

Name: The Triplet Chipper
Description: The Triplet Chipper is a grind/endurance workout performed "For Time," challenging both muscular stamina and cardiovascular endurance. Athletes complete three movements or exercises ("triplet") in sequence, usually with high repetitions. The goal is to finish all assigned reps of each movement before moving to the next, tackling the entire workout as quickly as possible with minimal rest. This format promotes full-body conditioning, mental toughness, and pacing strategy. Great for all fitness levels, the chipper structure is ideal for pushing personal limits and tracking progress over time.
Flavor_Text: The Triplet Chipper – A full-body punch that rewards tidy technique and calm transitions.
CoachNotes: For The Triplet Chipper: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions

Name: Heavy Hold Penalty II
Description: Heavy Hold Penalty II is a grind/endurance workout performed for time. This advanced session challenges both grip strength and overall muscular endurance. Athletes complete prescribed heavy holds (such as farmer’s carry or kettlebell holds) for set durations or distances. After each hold, a penalty exercise (like burpees, push-ups, or air squats) is immediately performed before continuing. The goal is to finish the entire sequence as quickly as possible while maintaining strict form and focus under fatigue. This workout builds mental toughness, increases total-body strength, and improves work capacity.
Flavor_Text: Heavy Hold Penalty II – Classic for-time intensity: aggressive but controlled from the first rep.
CoachNotes: For Heavy Hold Penalty II: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 250m Row. After each Row, perform 1m 0s of Dual Kettlebell Front Rack Hold (Heavy). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 500m Row. After each Row, perform 1m 0s of Dual Kettlebell Front Rack Hold (Heavy). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 500m Row. After each Row, perform 1m 0s of Dual Kettlebell Front Rack Hold (Heavy). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 500m Row. After each Row, perform 1m 0s of Dual Kettlebell Front Rack Hold (Heavy). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 500m row. after each row, perform 1m 0s of dual kettlebell front rack hold (heavy).
Instructions_Clean: 500m row. after each row, perform 1m 0s of dual kettlebell front rack hold (heavy).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Aim for unbroken swings if possible; hinge from the hips.

Name: Ski/row/pull
Description: A high-intensity endurance workout focused on full-body conditioning and cardiovascular stamina. Complete a set distance or number of calories on the ski erg, rower, or pull machine as quickly as possible. Aim for consistent pacing and efficient technique from start to finish. This grind-style session develops aerobic capacity, muscular endurance, and mental toughness, making it ideal for building long-lasting fitness.
Flavor_Text: Ski/row/pull – A straightforward suffer-fest; clean mechanics matter more than hero splits.
CoachNotes: For Ski/row/pull: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Scapular pull-ups, ring rows or banded pull-ups

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 250m Ski, 7 Pull-ups, 250m Row. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 500m Ski, 15 Pull-ups, 500m Row. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 500m Ski, 15 Pull-ups, 500m Row. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 500m Ski, 15 Pull-ups, 500m Row. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 500m ski, 15 pull-ups, 500m row.
Instructions_Clean: 500m ski, 15 pull-ups, 500m row.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Use kip efficiently; consider banded pull-ups to keep turnover high.

Name: Calorie Pyramid
Description: The Calorie Pyramid is a high-intensity, monostructural (cardio-focused) workout designed to challenge cardiovascular endurance and stamina. Athletes perform a single-cardio modality (such as rowing, biking, or running), completing an ascending and then descending pyramid of calorie targets “for time.” The goal is to move efficiently, pace each interval, and finish all required calories as quickly as possible. This workout promotes aerobic capacity, calorie burn, and mental toughness.
Flavor_Text: Calorie Pyramid – Build aerobic grit with honest pacing and controlled breathing.
CoachNotes: For Calorie Pyramid: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 5/3 Cal Ski, 10/7 Cal Row, 15/10 Cal Ski, 10/7 Cal Row, 5/3 Cal Ski. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 10/7 Cal Ski, 20/15 Cal Row, 30/21 Cal Ski, 20/15 Cal Row, 10/7 Cal Ski. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 10/7 Cal Ski, 20/15 Cal Row, 30/21 Cal Ski, 20/15 Cal Row, 10/7 Cal Ski. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 10/7 Cal Ski, 20/15 Cal Row, 30/21 Cal Ski, 20/15 Cal Row, 10/7 Cal Ski. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 10/7 cal ski, 20/15 cal row, 30/21 cal ski, 20/15 cal row, 10/7 cal ski.
Instructions_Clean: 10/7 cal ski, 20/15 cal row, 30/21 cal ski, 20/15 cal row, 10/7 cal ski.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: High Rep Thruster III
Description: High Rep Thruster III (Grind/endurance, For Time) is a full-body, metabolic conditioning workout designed to build muscular endurance and mental toughness. The workout features a high volume of thruster repetitions—combining a front squat and overhead press—performed continuously for time. Expect to challenge your legs, core, shoulders, and cardiovascular system. Maintain consistent pacing and efficient movement to grind through fatigue and complete the designated reps as quickly as possible. Ideal for athletes seeking to improve work capacity, stamina, and total body strength under fatigue.
Flavor_Text: High Rep Thruster III – Benchmark-style grit: push the clock without letting form fall apart.
CoachNotes: For High Rep Thruster III: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 12 Thrusters (37/12.4 kgs), 125m Row, 125m Ski. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 25 Thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 250m Row, 250m Ski. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 25 Thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 250m Row, 250m Ski. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 25 Thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 250m Row, 250m Ski. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 25 thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 250m row, 250m ski.
Instructions_Clean: 25 thrusters (75/24.9 kgs), 250m row, 250m ski.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Break thrusters into manageable sets; keep front rack tight.

Name: Running Row Triplet
Description: The Running Row Triplet is a high-intensity, cardio-focused workout that combines running, rowing, and bodyweight movements for time. Designed to boost cardiovascular endurance and muscular stamina, athletes will cycle through running intervals, vigorous rowing on an erg, and a third complementary exercise such as air squats or push-ups. The challenge is to complete all prescribed rounds as quickly as possible, emphasizing pace consistency and efficient transitions between stations. Suitable for all levels with scalable distances and reps.
Flavor_Text: Running Row Triplet – Long, steady output; aim for a rhythm you could explain, not survive.
CoachNotes: For Running Row Triplet: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 250m Row, 200m Run, 250m Row. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 500m Row, 400m Run, 500m Row. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 500m Row, 400m Run, 500m Row. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 500m Row, 400m Run, 500m Row. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 500m row, 400m run, 500m row.
Instructions_Clean: 500m row, 400m run, 500m row.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Max Distance 15
Description: Max Distance 15 is a monostructural cardio workout where you aim to cover the greatest distance possible in 15 minutes. Choose a single modality such as running, rowing, biking, or skiing. Maintain a steady, challenging pace throughout the interval, focusing on efficient technique and endurance. This workout builds cardiovascular capacity and mental stamina. Record total distance achieved to track progress over time.
Flavor_Text: Max Distance 15 – A skill-forward piece; keep mechanics clean and ego low.
CoachNotes: For Max Distance 15: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike)

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: AMRAP in 7m 0s: 50m Ski, 50m Row, 5 Burpees. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: AMRAP in 15m 0s: 100m Ski, 100m Row, 10 Burpees. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: AMRAP in 15m 0s: 100m Ski, 100m Row, 10 Burpees. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: AMRAP in 15m 0s: 100m Ski, 100m Row, 10 Burpees. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: amrap in 15m 0s: 100m ski, 100m row, 10 burpees.
Instructions_Clean: amrap in 15m 0s: 100m ski, 100m row, 10 burpees.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Synchronized
Description: The Synchronized is a grind and endurance-based team workout performed for time. Team members complete movements simultaneously, requiring coordination and communication. The focus is on maintaining a steady, sustainable pace together, pushing through each exercise efficiently, and supporting each other to finish as quickly as possible. This workout builds teamwork, cardiovascular endurance, muscular stamina, and mental toughness.
Flavor_Text: The Synchronized – Communication, trust, and tempo matter more than any single split.
CoachNotes: For The Synchronized: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Air squats and goblet squats progression, ankle mobility

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 10 Synchronized Burpees (must hit the ground/jump together), 15 Synchronized Air Squats, 20 Wall Balls (Split Reps). - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 20 Synchronized Burpees (must hit the ground/jump together), 30 Synchronized Air Squats, 40 Wall Balls (Split Reps). - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 20 Synchronized Burpees (must hit the ground/jump together), 30 Synchronized Air Squats, 40 Wall Balls (Split Reps). - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 20 Synchronized Burpees (must hit the ground/jump together), 30 Synchronized Air Squats, 40 Wall Balls (Split Reps). - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 20 synchronized burpees (must hit the ground/jump together), 30 synchronized air squats, 40 wall balls (split reps).
Instructions_Clean: 20 synchronized burpees (must hit the ground/jump together), 30 synchronized air squats, 40 wall balls (split repetitions).
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Set a rhythm and target the top of the wall mark consistently.

Name: You Go, I Go Clean
Description: "You Go, I Go Clean" is a partner AMRAP (As Many Rounds As Possible) interval workout performed over 16 minutes. Teams of two alternate turns: Partner A completes a set of cleans, then rests while Partner B works. Each partner pushes for max reps or rounds, encouraging fast-paced effort and teamwork. The format allows built-in rest, improving intensity, barbell cycling, and camaraderie during the workout.
Flavor_Text: You Go, I Go Clean – Perfect for sharpening teamwork under controlled chaos.
CoachNotes: For You Go, I Go Clean: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Partner 1: 2 Clean & Jerks (67/21.1 kgs). Partner 1: Holds plank. P1 finishes, P1 immediately starts 2 C&Js. Score is total C&Js. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Partner 1: 5 Clean & Jerks (135/43.1 kgs). Partner 2: Holds plank. P1 finishes, P2 immediately starts 5 C&Js. Score is total C&Js. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Partner 1: 5 Clean & Jerks (135/43.1 kgs). Partner 2: Holds plank. P1 finishes, P2 immediately starts 5 C&Js. Score is total C&Js. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Partner 1: 5 Clean & Jerks (135/43.1 kgs). Partner 2: Holds plank. P1 finishes, P2 immediately starts 5 C&Js. Score is total C&Js. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: partner 1: 5 clean & jerks (135/43.1 kgs). partner 2: holds plank. p1 finishes, p2 immediately starts 5 c&js. score is total c&js.
Instructions_Clean: partner 1: 5 clean & jerks (135/43.1 kgs). partner 2: holds plank. p1 finishes, p2 immediately starts 5 c&js. score is total c&js.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: Pacer Tax
Description: Pacer Tax is a team endurance workout designed to build mental toughness and cardiovascular stamina. Teams work together to complete a set distance or number of rounds as quickly as possible ("For Time"). The pace is determined by a designated "pacer" whose performance dictates team progress. The workout emphasizes consistent effort, teamwork, and the ability to push through fatigue. Ideal for improving work capacity, pacing strategy, and camaraderie under pressure.
Flavor_Text: Pacer Tax – Trade work, trade lungs; push hard while your partner watches.
CoachNotes: For Pacer Tax: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Shoulder activation: band pull-aparts, push-up progressions; Strides or ramped efforts for 6x20s

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: Partner 1 runs 200m. While P1 runs, P1 completes max rounds of: 5 Push-ups, 7 Sit-ups. Switch roles. Score is time to complete all 2 runs + total work. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: Partner 1 runs 400m. While P1 runs, P2 completes max rounds of: 10 Push-ups, 15 Sit-ups. Switch roles. Score is time to complete all 5 runs + total work. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: Partner 1 runs 400m. While P1 runs, P2 completes max rounds of: 10 Push-ups, 15 Sit-ups. Switch roles. Score is time to complete all 5 runs + total work. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: Partner 1 runs 400m. While P1 runs, P2 completes max rounds of: 10 Push-ups, 15 Sit-ups. Switch roles. Score is time to complete all 5 runs + total work. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: partner 1 runs 400m. while p1 runs, p2 completes max rounds of: 10 push-ups, 15 sit-ups. switch roles. score is time to complete all 5 runs + total work.
Instructions_Clean: partner 1 runs 400m. while p1 runs, p2 completes max rounds of: 10 push-ups, 15 sit-ups. switch roles. score is time to complete all 5 runs + total work.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint.

Name: The Farmer's Trade
Description: The Farmer's Trade is a grind/endurance team workout performed for time. Teams work together to transport heavy objects (often dumbbells or kettlebells), simulating a “farmer’s carry.” The objective is to complete all prescribed carry distances and/or repetitions as quickly as possible, emphasizing teamwork, grip strength, stamina, and consistent pacing. Each team member alternates carries, ensuring sustained effort and minimal rest throughout the workout. The workout challenges mental toughness, coordination, and cardiovascular endurance.
Flavor_Text: The Farmer's Trade – Shared suffering; clean handovers and honest effort keep the team moving.
CoachNotes: For The Farmer's Trade: Focus on consistent pacing, maintain proper form throughout, and scale appropriately to preserve workout stimulus. Break up reps strategically and prioritize breathing rhythm. See CrossFit.com for detailed guidance.
Warmup: 5-10m 0s general cardio (row/jog/bike); Hip hinge mobility: kettlebell deadlift warm-up, Romanian deadlift 3x8

Scaling_Tiers.Beginner: 50 ft Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy, Partners hold same KBs), 2 Box Jumps (P1 works, P1 rests). Total 50 Box Jumps. - Beginner: lighter loads, banded/assistance, reduced volume.
Scaling_Tiers.Intermediate: 100 ft Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy, Partners hold same KBs), 5 Box Jumps (P1 works, P2 rests). Total 100 Box Jumps. - Intermediate: moderate loads, standard scaling.
Scaling_Tiers.Advanced: 100 ft Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy, Partners hold same KBs), 5 Box Jumps (P1 works, P2 rests). Total 100 Box Jumps. - Advanced: Rx or add weight/tempo.
Scaling_Tiers.Limited Equipment: 100 ft Dual Kettlebell Farmer's Carry (Heavy, Partners hold same KBs), 5 Box Jumps (P1 works, P2 rests). Total 100 Box Jumps. - Limited equipment: substitute barbells with dumbbells/kettlebells, row with running.

Instructions: 100 ft dual kettlebell farmer's carry (heavy, partners hold same kbs), 5 box jumps (p1 works, p2 rests). total 100 box jumps.
Instructions_Clean: 100 ft dual kettlebell farmer's carry (heavy, partners hold same kbs), 5 box jumps (p1 works, p2 rests). total 100 box jumps.
ScalingOptions: Reduce reps, lighten load, or modify gymnastics (e.g., banded pull-ups, lighter KB, shortened run distances).
Coaching_Cues: Pace the workout according to the time domain; avoid all-out opening bursts unless short sprint. Aim for unbroken swings if possible; hinge from the hips.
